title-group.article-title: Drop-weight impact damage of three-dimensional angle-interlock woven composites

contrib-group.aff: College of Textiles, Ministry of Education, Donghua University, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: B Gu, College of Textiles, Key Laboratory of High-Performance Fibers & Products, Ministry of Education, Donghua University, Shanghai, China 201620. Email: gubh@dhu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The drop-weight impact behavior of three-dimensional angle-interlock woven glass fiber/unsaturated polyester resin composites was investigated with a drop-weight impact tester (Instron Dynatup 9250 impact tester). A unit cell model based on the maximum stress failure criterion and critical damage area failure theory was established to define the material properties and stiffness degradation of the three-dimensional angle-interlock woven composites. A user-defined subroutine vectorized user-material was developed to connect with the commercial finite element analysis package ABAQUS/Explicit. The drop-weight impact damage and impact load-displacement curves were calculated and compared with those in the experimental. Good agreements between the experimental and finite element analysis results proved the validity of the unit cell model and the subroutine vectorized user-material. The unit cell model is expected to be extended for the study of the impact damage of three-dimensional angle-interlock woven composites structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Textile composite structures, owing to their intrinsic high specific mechanical properties, have been widely used in the areas as aerospace, automobile parts, construction engineering, etc. Three-dimensional (3D) textile composites have higher strength and impact resistance because of fibers along thickness direction as compared with two-dimensional (2D) composites. As one of the 3D textile composites, the three-dimensional angle-interlock woven composites (3DAWC) have received increased attention in engineering because of its high strength and high damage resistance attributed to interlaced structure of the warp and weft between the adjacent layers.1

The mechanical behaviors of 3DAWC have been investigated by several researchers so far. Whitney and Chou2 developed a model based on constituent micro-cells to predict the in-plain elastic properties of the 3D angle-interlock structural composites. Byun and Chou3 and Cox et al.4 studied the compressive failure of the 3DAWC under uni-axial monotonic compression. Chen et al.5 experimentally developed the relations between the processing parameters and the properties of 3DAWC. Tsai et al.6 investigated the fatigue process of 3DAWCs under tensile cyclic stress. Huang and Zhong7 conducted series of experiments and found that fabric structure had a strong effect on the tensile strength and the dimensional stability of the composite. Tan et al.8 established a finite element analysis (FEA) model and two analytical models based on the laminate block modeling approach to estimate the mechanical and thermomechanical properties of the 3D through-thickness angle-interlock woven composites, it was concluded that there is good agreement between these FEA and analytical models. Naik et al.9 presented a strength model based on repeating unit cell to predict the stress and failure behavior of 3DAWC under static tensile loading and shear loading. Sheng and Van Hoa10 proposed a mechanical model based on the micro fabric geometry for several 3DAWC to predict elastic constants of 3DAWC. Yanjun et al.11 proposed a micromechanical model that considers the fabric geometry for elastic constants of 3D angle-interlock woven ceramic composites and analyzed the effects of various parameters of fabric geometry on the elastic properties. Sun and Gu12 investigated the stress–strain behavior of 3DAWC at various strain rates and used Fourier transform and wavelet analysis method to study the stress waves at frequency domain and time-frequency domain. Schneider et al.13 tested the quasi-static tension and torsion behaviors of a carbon/epoxy layer–layer angle interlock composites and proposed a macroscopic viscoelastic damage model for 3D interlock woven with polymer matrices.

For the impact behaviors of the 3DAWC, Li et al.14 developed a unit cell model incorporated with the critical damage area (CDA) failure theory to investigate the ballistic impact behavior of 3DAWC. Cui et al.15 created ‘Fiber inclination model’ from finite element code LS-DYNA to simulate the ballistic performance of 3DAWC. Lapeyronnie et al.16 developed a numerical tool from periodic homogenization method to study the elastic behavior of 3D layer-to-layer angle-interlock composites. Chiu et al.17 experimentally investigated the residual compressive strength and micro-failure mechanism of 3D interlock woven/epoxy composites. An instrumented drop weight impact testing system was used to induce damage in the 3D composites, and ultrasonic C-scan and optical microscopy were used to identify the damage areas and micro-failure mechanisms after low-energy impact. Dong and Song18 examined the impact and tensile performances of both 3D woven composites and 2D woven laminated composites. Compared to the 2D woven composites, the 3D woven composites have better impact properties, the energy required to initiate cracks, the threshold force of the first oscillation and maximum load increased by 41.90%, 54.41% and 38.75%, respectively, under the low-energy impact conditions.

However, little attention has been paid to the low-velocity impact behavior of 3DAWC in theoretical, especially from numerical simulations. With the numerical simulations, the influence of microstructure parameters on the impact behaviors could be revealed and the microstructure could be optimized. In this paper, a unit cell model that was previously proposed by author’s group, Li et al.,14 has been further developed on the basis of maximum stress criterion and CDA failure theory to investigate the drop-weight impact behavior of the 3DAWC. The commercial finite element package ABAQUS/Explicit connected with user-defined subroutine vectorized user-material (VUMAT) was employed to calculate the damage process of 3DAWC. The load-displacement histories and failure mode were obtained from finite element method (FEM) calculation and verified by experimental results. The unit-cell model was verified with the experimental results and the validity of the unit-cell model was found. We hope such a unit-cell model could be extended to the impact behaviors design for the 3D woven composite structures.

sec.title: Three-dimensional angle-interlock woven composites
sec.p:
A 3D angle-interlock woven fabric (3DAWF) with layer-to-layer angle-interlock structure was developed in this study, as shown in Figure 1. Table 1 listed the specifications of the fabric. The linear density of glass warp yarn is 960dtex and that of glass weft yarn is 480dtex (tex is a unit of linear density, meaning the weight in gram of a fiber with length of one kilometer. Units = g/km = (g/cm) × 10−5, 10 dtex = 1 tex). The 3DAWC was processed by injecting unsaturated polyester resin into the 3DAWF with vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding (VARTM) technique. We used burning method (Muffle furnace) to measure the fiber volume fraction. The fiber volume fraction is 55%. The beam-like composite specimen (width being much smaller than length, instead of plate-like) was used to test the drop-weight impact behaviors. The impact penetration and also the impact bending deformation could be obtained from the beam-like specimen. The composite was cut into the size of 200 mm × 20 mm × 4 mm by water jet technique. Figure 2 illustrated the surface and cross-section of the composite. Figure 1.
Schematic sketch of three-dimensional (3D) angle-interlock woven fabric.
Figure 2.
Photograph of three-dimensional (3D) angle-interlock woven composites.
Table 1.
Specifications of 3D angle-interlock woven fabric
Weaving density Length of the fabric Liner density of the yarns
Weft 2 (ends/cm) 350 mm 480 dtex × 1 ply
Warp 11 (ends/cm) 1200 mm 480 dtex × 2 plies

sec.title: Impact tester
sec.p:
The Instron Dynatup 9250 drop weight impact tester was used to test the low-velocity impact behavior of 3DAWC. As shown in Figure 3, the impact test system consists of cross girder, guiding rods, added mass chest, electronic sensor, impactor etc. The impact energy of the impactor ranges from 2.6 J to 1603 J with impact velocity up to 20 m/s. Figure 3.
Instron Dynatup 9250 drop weight impact tester.

A fixture for the tester was constructed to confirm the stability of the specimens as shown in Figure 4. The composite specimen was tightened strongly to prevent the in-plane motion of the specimen ends. In drop-weight tests, a conical cup with a diameter of 25 mm and a cone angle of 45° was employed (shown in Figure 5) to investigate the impact penetration damage of the 3DAWC. Figure 4.
Fixture for composite samples.
Figure 5.
Conical impactor.

sec.title: Drop-weight impact tests
sec.p: A series of drop-weight impact tests was conducted to determine the impact load-displacement curves of the composite specimens. The impact energies of 10 J, 30 J, 50 J and 70 J were used in impact tests achieved by adjusting the falling height of the impactor while keeping the weight of the impactor constant at 11.37 kg (plus added mass). The specimens were clamped on two ends as shown in Figure 4. The effective test region is 110 mm × 20 mm. Three samples were tested for each impact energy. The load-displacement curves during impact were obtained and the damage morphologies of the samples were observed.

sec.title: Unit cell modeling
sec.p:
Figure 6 shows a unit cell model for the 3DAWC. This model was established by the authors of this paper.14 The unit cell consists of three parts: resin, weft yarns and warp yarns. The volume fraction of each part in the unit cell was equal to that of entire 3DAWC. The warp yarn could be simplified as straight lines (Part A and B) and an arc (Part C), as shown in Figure 7. In the unit cell, a global Cartesian coordinate system (x, y and z) was established in which the axis x, y and z were defined as longitudinal (warp yarn), transverse (weft yarn) and thickness direction, respectively. A local coordinate system (direction 1, direction 2 and direction 3) was also set up for each yarn, as shown in Figure 8. Figure 6.
Simplified unit cell model.
Figure 7.
Unit cell model.
Figure 8.
Local coordinate system.

sec.title: Resin volume fraction
sec.p: AssumingVm is resin volume fraction: (1)Vm=28%×wρmv where 28% is the mass fraction of resin, w is the mass of the composite, ρm is the matrix density and v is the volume of composite. Then the resin volume fraction could be calculated from the resin weight fraction using equation (1).

Fiber volume fraction. Assuming Vweft is volume fraction of weft yarn: (2)Vweft=nvweft0v where n is the number of weft yarns, vweft0 is the volume of each weft yarn obtained by direct test and v is the volume of composite.
Assuming Vwarp is volume fraction of warp yarn: (3)Vwarp=1-Vm-Vweft where Vm is the volume fraction of matrix and Vweft is the volume fraction of weft yarns.

sec.title: Stiffness and compliance matrix of the unit cell
Resin
sec.p: The resin is assumed as an isotropic material.
Assuming [S ]m is the compliance matrix of the resin: (4) [S ]m= [1/Em-ν/Em-ν/Em000-ν/Em1/Em-ν/Em000-ν/Em-ν/Em1/Em0000001/Gm0000001/Gm0000001/Gm ]
Thus, the stiffness matrix of the resin is [C ]m= [S ]m -1.

sec.title: Fiber tows
sec.p: Glass fiber tows is assumed as a transverse-isotropic materials.
Assuming [S ]y is the compliance matrix of the fiber tow (5) [S ]y= [S11 (y)S12 (y)S12 (y)000S12 (y)S22 (y)S23 (y)000S12 (y)S23 (y)S22 (y)0000002(S22 (y)-S23 (y))000000S55 (y)000000S55 (y) ]
Then, the stiffness matrix of the fiber tow is [C ]y= [S ]y -1.

sec.title: Weft yarns
sec.p: The weft yarns are perpendicular to the x-axis in global Cartesian coordinate system. Assuming [S ]weft is the compliance matrix of weft yarn in global Cartesian coordinate system. [S ]weft= [Tw ]-1 [S ]y [Tw ] where [Tw ] is the strain transformation matrix of weft yarn, given by: (6) [Tw ]= [l1 2m1 2n1 22m1n12l1n12l1m1l2 2m2 2n2 22m2n22l2n22l2m2l3 2m3 2n3 22m3n32l3n32l3m3l2l3m2m3n2n3m2n3+m3n2l2n3+l3n2l2m3+l3m2l1l3m1m3n1n3m1n3+m3n1l1n3+l3n1l1m3+l3m1l1l2m1m2n1n2m1n2+m2n1l1n2+l2n1l1m2+l2m1 ] where li=cos(i,x), mi=cos(i,y), ni=cos(i,z) i=(1,2,3) is the direction cosine from local Cartesian coordinate system to global Cartesian coordinate system.

sec.title: Warp yarns
sec.p: Warp yarn consists of three parts: Part A (crossing angle between straight line of warp yarn and x-axis is 30°), Part B (crossing angle between straight line of warp yarn and x-axis is -30°) and Part C (circular arc).
For Part A:

Assuming [S ]A is the compliance matrix of the warp yarn in global Cartesian coordinate system: [S ]A= [TA ]-1 [S ]y [TA ] where [TA ] is the strain transformation matrix for Part A, and l1=-0.86,l2=0,l3=0.5,m1=0,m2=1,m3=0,n1=0.5,n2=0,n3=0.86
For Part B:

Assuming [S ]B is the compliance matrix of the warp yarn in global Cartesian Coordinate system: [S ]B= [TB ]-1 [S ]y [TB ] where [TB ] is the strain transformation matrix for Part B, and l1=0.86, l2=0, l3=-0.5, m1=0, m2=1, m3=0, n1=0.5, n2=0, n3=0.86.
For Part C:

Assuming [S ]C is the compliance matrix of the warp yarn in global Cartesian coordinate system: [S ]C=12θ∫-θ θ [S¯ ]Cdθ where [S¯ ]C= [TC ]-1 [S ]y [TC ], [TC ] is the strain transformation matrix for Part C and θ is the crossing angle between warp yarn and x-axis.

Invariable step-size trapezoid formula is adopted to solve the equation: (7) [S ]C=12θ∫-θ θ [S¯ ]Cdθ=14θh [ [T-θ ]-1 [S ]y [T-θ ]+ [Tθ ]-1 [S ]y [Tθ ]+2∑i-1 n-1 [T-θ+h ]-1 [S ]y [T-θ+h ] ] ×θ∈ (-30∘,30∘ ) where h is the partition number of circular arc.

sec.title: Stiffness of unit cell
sec.p:
Tan et al.8 proposed a mixed iso-strain and iso-stress named as X-model, Y-model and Z-model, based on unit cell mode to predict the mechanical and thermo-elastic properties of 3DAWC materials. The unit cell was simplified as four cubic blocks in the present study, as shown in Figure 9. The properties of unit cell were estimated by summing the properties of every block. Such a unit-cell model was employed and implemented in the FEM model for calculating the drop-weight impact damage of the 3DAWC. Figure 9.
The illustration of the X-model, Y-model, and Z-model.
(1) Elastic constants

In the process of FEA, the inclined unidirectional lamina was regarded as transverse isotropic material whose mechanical properties can be reduced from the material properties of the fibers and the resin. The fibers were treated as transverse isotropic material. The unsaturated polyester resin was considered as isotropic material. Based on the material properties, the fiber volume fraction Vf and the resin volume fraction Vm, the mechanical properties of the inclined unidirectional lamina can be calculated according to the equations as follows19: (8)Ex=VfEf+(1-Vf)EmEy=Em(1+Vf)1-VfGxy=Gm(1+2Vf)1-VfGxz=GxyGyz=Gm1-Vf(1-Gm/Gf)νxy=Vfνf+(1-Vf)νmνyx=νxyEy/Exνyz=Vfνf+(1-Vf)(2νm-νyz)
(2) X-model, Y-model and Z-model
As shown in Figure 9, an “X assembly” is assembled with NA blocks of material A and NB blocks of material B in the x direction. The overall material properties are given via the following equations:
(i) X-model8

(9)C11 S=C11 AC11 BNAVAC11 B+NBVBC11 AC12 S=C11 S [NAC12 AVAC11 A+NBC12 BVBC11 B ]C13 S=C11 S [NAC13 AVAC11 A+NBC13 BVBC11 B ]C22 S=NAC22 SVA+NBC22 BVBC23 S=NAC23 SVA+NBC23 BVBC33 S=NAC33 SVA+NBC33 BVBC44 S=NAC44 SVA+NBC44 BVBC55 S=NAC55 SVA+NBC55 BVBC66 S=C66 AC66 BNAVAC66 B+NBVBC66 A where NA and NB are the numbers of micro-blocks A and B within a strip, respectively, and VA and VB are the volume fractions of a micro-block A and a micro-block B in a strip, respectively, Cij A,Cij B and Cij S are the stiffness constants for a micro-block A, a microblock B and a strip, respectively.
(ii) Y-model

The overall material properties for the Y assembly block are given by the following equations: (10)C11 S=NAC11 AVA+NBC11 BVBC12 S=C22 S (NAC12 AVAC33 T+NBC12 BVBC33 B )C13 S=NAC13 AVA+NBC13 BVBC22 S=C22 AC22 BNAVAC22 B+NBVBC22 AC23 S=C22 S (NAC23 AVAC22 A+NBC23 BVBC22 A )C33 S=NAC33 AVA+NBC33 BVBC44 S=C44 AC44 BNAVAC44 B+NBVBC44 AC55 S=NAC55 AVA+NBC55 BVBC66 S=C66 AC66 BNAVAC66 B+NBVBC66 A
(iii) Z-model8

The equations required to calculate the overall material properties for the Z assembly are given as follows: (11)C11 S=NAC11 AVA+NBC11 BVBC12 S=NAC12 AVA+NBC12 BVBC13 S=C22 S (NAC13 AVAC22 A+NBC13 BVBC22 A )C22 S=NAC22 AVA+NBC22 BVBC23 S=C33 S (NAC23 AVAC33 A+NBC23 BVBC33 B )C33 S=C33 AC33 BNAVAC33 B+NBVBC33 AC44 S=C44 AC44 BNAVAC44 B+NBVBC44 AC55 S=C55 AC55 BNAVAC55 B+NBVBC55 AC66 S=NAC66 AVA+NBC66 BVB
It is worth pointing out that the principal axes of material blocks A and B are assumed to coincide with the Cartesian coordinates, x, y and z, for all the three assemblage schemes shown in Figure 9.

sec.title: Critical damaged area
sec.p: Composite failure is determined by not only the stresses present in the material but also the area where the stresses exceed critical values. This critical area is governed by the composite’s interaction length, which can be as low as 1 mm for tape-based composites and up to 100 mm for some 3D interlock weaves.20 The CDA criterion is necessary when considering composite failure because a composite will not necessarily fail when a single fiber, or even tow, exceeds its maximum stress. Instead, composite failure will occur only when: (1) stresses exceed the local fiber strength and (2) a critical damage area has reached. The critical area is calculated by applying Tsai-Hahn fiber-bundle theory,21,22 originally proposed by Rosen,23 to tows to calculate the critical interaction length δ.

The critical damaged length (δ) is defined as (25)δ=4γf (Xf4τy )κκ+1 [ (κ+1 )L2γf ]1κ+1 where γ is the tow radius, Xf is the average fiber tension strength, L is the tow length, typically assumed 1 unit length, τ is the matrix yield stress and κ is the Weibull parameter. As discussed by Rosen23 and Gucer et al.,24 the κ is the shape parameter of the Weibull distribution of the fiber strength distribution. Value of κ between 2 and 4 correspond to brittle ceramics, whereas a value of 20 is appropriate for a ductile metal. For the E-glass filament yarns, the κ is assumed to be 7.6.
The damage of composite must accord with two conditions. One condition is stresses in material beyond the strength of local fibers. The other is the stress area beyond the CDA.
If the CDA is square, it equals δ2. Before the damage of composite, fiber degradation increases with the critical damaged area.

The value of δ determined from equation (25) is only used as an approximation because of the assumption required for analysis and variations of the material parameters. For instance, the value of δ for typical graphite/epoxy composites range from 0.025 inches (0.0635 cm) to 0.060 inches (0.1524 cm).25 For E-glass/ vinyl ester resin composites, δ was found to be about 27 mm. (26)Ei=E0 i [1- (DA-DAf iCDA )2 ] where Ei is the E11 Young’s Modulus at point i, E0 is the undamaged modulus, CDA is the critical damaged area, DA is the current damaged area where the longitudinal stress has exceeded the tension strength of the composite XT and DAf i is the value of DA when point i exceeds its maximum stress.

sec.title: Failure behavior
sec.p: The resin and yarns was regarded to fail simultaneously and they were analyzed based on maximum stress failure criteria.
1). Resin degradation and failure

As mentioned above, the resin was assumed as isotropic material. The following analysis is mutually independent and if any stress is greater than the maximum stress, the material is considered as failed.
Tension failure in resin: IfδT>δult Tthen E=0.01×E,G=0.01×G where δT is the tension stress of the resin, E is the tension module and G is the shear module
Compression failure in resin: Ifδc<δult cthen E=0.01×E,G=0.01×G where δC is the compression stress of the resin.
Shear failure in resin: Ifτ>τultthen E=0.01×E,G=0.01×G where τ is the shear stress of the resin.
2) Fiber degradation and failure

The yarns were regarded as transverse-isotropic materials. Hence, the maximum stress in different directions of the fiber was different. The yarns will fail if the stress in any direction exceeded its maximum stress or the damage area is greater than the critical damage area.

(1) Longitudinal (1-direction) failure in the tows
Tension failure in the longitudinal directionBased on the maximum stress theory and CDA criteria: Ifδ11>δult T,thenCDALi+1=CDALi+1ifδ11>δult T CDALi+1>CDA,thenE11=0,G12=0,G13=0 where CDAL0 = 0, CDALi is used as a counter, δ11 T is the tension stress of the fiber in 1-direction, E11 is the tension module 1-direction, G12 is the shear module of the fiber in 1-2 plane and G13 is shear module of the fiber in 1–3 plane.
Compression failure in the longitudinal direction. Based on the maximum stress theory: Ifδ11<δult C,thenE11=0.95*E11,δ11=δult C where δ11 C is the compression stress of the fiber in 1-direction.

(2) Transverse (2, 3-direction) failure in the tows
Tension failure in 2 -direction. Based on the maximum stress theory: Ifδ22 T>δult TthenE22=0,G12=0,G23=0 where δ22 T is the tension stress in 2-direction of the fiber, E22is the tension module of the fiber in the 2-direction and G23=0 is the shear module of the fiber in 1-3 plane.
Compression failure in 2-direction. Based on the maximum stress theory: Ifδ22 C<δult C,thenδ22=δult C,Δδ22=0 where δ22 C is the compression stress in 2-direction of the fiber.
Tension failure of 3-direction. Based on the maximum stress theory: Ifδ33 T>δult T,thenE33=0,G13=0,G23=0 where δ33 T is the tension stress in 3-direction of the fiber and E33is the tension module of the fiber in 3-direction.
Compression failure in 3-direction. Based on the maximum stress theory: Ifδ33 C<δult 3C,thenδ33 C=δult C,Δδ33=0 where δ33 C is the compression stress in 3-direction of the fiber.

(3) Shear failure in tows. Based on the maximum stress theory and CDA criteria:
Shear failure in 1-2 plane Ifδ12 S>δ12ult sthenG12=0,CDALi+1=CDALi+1 where δ12 S is shear stress of the fiber in 1-2 plane.
Shear failure in 1–3 plane Ifδ1 3 S>δ13ult s,thenG13=0,CDALi+1=CDALi+1 where δ13 S is the shear stress of the fiber in 1-3 plane.
Shear failure in 2-3 plane Ifδ2 3 S>δ23ult s,thenG23=0,CDALi+1=CDALi+1 where δ23 S is the shear stress of the fiber 2–3 plane.

sec.title: Finite element simulations
sec.p:
The finite element code ABAQUS/Explicit 6.10 was used for the drop-weight impact simulation on a Windows XP OS platform. The user-defined material (VUMAT) subroutine was complied by MS Visual C ++ 6.0 in the compiling language of Compad FORTRAN compiler 6.6. The flow chart of the operating principle of the VUMAT is shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
Flow chart of the vectorized user-material (VUMAT).

Due to the symmetry, only half of the composite panel and the impactor were modeled with the finite element solver ABAQUS/Explicit, as shown in Figure 11. The size of the composite panel sample was 200 mm × 10 mm × 4 mm. The composite and the impactor were meshed with C3D8R and C3D4 elements, which were an eight-node linear brick and four-node linear tetrahedron elements, respectively, with reduced integration. The numbers of element used for the composite sample and the impactor were 13536 and 4430, respectively. Figure 11.
Finite element geometrical model of the composite sample and the conical impactor.

The impactor was modeled as rigid body with no freedom of displacement and rotation expect the displacement along normal impact direction. It had a conical shaped impact surface with a diameter of 25 mm and a cone angle of 45° as shown in Figure 5. The two sides of the composite panel were restrained by the “SYMMETRY/ANTISYMMETRY/ENCASTRE” boundary condition. The relative parameters of the impactor and the 3DAWC are shown in Tables 2–5. Table 2.
Conical impactor
E (GPa) Density (g/cm3) ν
200 7.8 0.3
Table 3.
Mechanical parameters of resin
E (GPa)G (GPa)νXT (MPa)XC (MPa)SS (MPa)
8.4 3.1 0.38 368 200 168
XT: tensile strength along X direction; XC: compressive strength along X direction; SS: shear strength.
Table 4.
Stiffness parameters of glass fiber tows
E11 (GPa)E22 (GPa)E33 (GPa)G12 (GPa)G13 (GPa)G23 (GPa)ν12ν23ν13
88 80 80 35.2 35.2 33 0.25 0.21 0.25
Table 5.
Strength parameters of glass fiber tows
Yarn XT (MPa) XC (MPa) YT (MPa) YC (MPa) SS12 (MPa) SS23 (MPa)
Weft 5000 −5000 4000 −4000 1600 1400
Warp 5500 −5500 4250 −4250 1700 1500
XT: tensile strength along X direction; XC: compressive strength along X direction; YT: tensile strength along Y direction; YC: compressive strength along Y direction; SS: shear strength.

sec.title: Load–displacement curves
sec.p:
Figure 12 shows the load-displacement curves under different impact energies obtained from the Instron Dynatup 9250 impact tester. All the curves could be recorded during the impact tests. The increase of impact energy is accompanied by the increase in the maximum impact load and displacement. The initial part of all the curves have almost the same slope meaning that the 3DAWC has the same stiffness under the impact energy range from 10 J to 70 J. The peak load increases with the increase of impact energy but due to the occurrence of impact damage, the increment becomes low under the impact energies of 30 J, 50 J and 70 J. The difference of the maximum load under the impact energy of 10 J and 30 J is bigger than that between impact energy of 30 J and 50 J, while the difference between impact energy of 50 J and 70 J was the smallest. It was concluded that with the increase of the impact energy, the damage will occur and the energy absorption of the composite will reach a maximum value. Before the impact energy of 30 J, the impact load increases by about 56%, in this period, the composite had a rapid increase of impact energy absorption. After the impact energy of 50 J, the impact load increases by about only 7%, which reveals that the damage area of the composite nearly reaches its limit or the absorbed energy by the composite cannot increase further. At the same time, the increasing range of displacement is comparatively the same corresponding to the level of increase in impact energy. Figure 12.
Impact load–displacement curves at four impact energies.

Figure 13 shows the comparison of the load-displacement curves between FEM and experimental. The maximum load was generally well predicted; however, the maximum displacements were underestimated especially at the impact energy of 50 J and 70 J as shown in Figure 13(c) and (d). From Figure 13, it was shown that the impact load increases rapidly and fluctuates slightly due to the initial damage in the composite, and then reaches a peak value rapidly. After this peak value, the impact load fluctuates due to the different types of damages such as matrix cracks, fiber breakage, etc. With the propagation of the matrix cracks and fiber breakage, the impact load experiences an elastic recovery or sudden drop due to the reduction of the local and global stiffness of the composites caused by these damages. Figure 13.
Comparisons of impact load–displacement curves under different impact energies between experimental and FEM.

Figure 14 shows the FEM results of the deflection of the composite panel at the location of the impact point. In the case of 70 J, the maximum deflection is seven times larger than the total thickness of the composite. The composite almost reaches complete failure and the damage area of the composite reaches the limit value. Figure 14.
Deflections of the composites at the impact position.

sec.title: Failure evolution
sec.p:
Figure 15 shows the FEM results of damage evolution of the 3DAWC under low-velocity impact, for example, at the impact energy of 30 J. The element will be deleted if the stress is greater than its maximum stress. It could be seen that the first element distortion occurred at about 0.9 ms and the first element deletion at 3.7 ms. The penetration of the impactor occurred at 7.0 ms where the impact load reaches almost the peak value and then fluctuates abruptly as shown in Figure 13(b). As the impactor penetrates the sample, the contact area between the impactor and the composite increases up to a maximum value. Figure 15.
Damage evolution of the composite under the impact energy of 30 J.
Figure 16.
Comparison of impact damage between experimental and FEM.

sec.title: Final failure morphology
sec.p: The final failure morphologies of the composite obtained from the experimental and the FEM simulation are compared in Figure 16. It was found that the hole morphology between experimental and FEM was comparable. With the increase of impact energy, the damage area becomes larger and the phenomenon of matrix cracks, fiber breakage and matrix or fiber pullout becomes apparent. At the impact energy of 70 J, the fiber pull-out was clearly observed as the strength of the fibers had reached its maximum value at this stage.

sec.title: Future design
sec.p: From the comparisons between FEM calculation and experimental, we found that the unit-cell model developed for the 3DAWC was successfully applied to the calculation of drop-weight impact damage and energy absorption. Because the microstructure parameters and mechanical behaviors of the constituent materials can be adjusted, the different impact damage tolerances could be obtained from changing the parameters. Then, the desired impact behaviors of the 3DAWC can be obtained. This calculation will save a lot of experimental costs and testing time. From the unit-cell model and the FEM subroutine, the impact responses of the engineering structures, such as T-beam, I-beam or tubes, which is made of the 3DAWC, can be designed and optimized.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The drop-weight impact tests for the 3DAWC panel have been conducted at the impact energy of 10 J, 30 J, 50 J and 70 J in the Instron Dynatup 9250 impact tester. The impact load-displacement curves have been recorded and the impact damage morphologies have been observed. A unit cell model based on the maximum stress criterion and CDA failure theory was established. Based on the unit-cell model, a VUMAT subroutine with FORTRAN language was developed. The subroutine was connected with the commercial FEM package ABAQUS/Explicit to simulate the low-velocity impact behavior of 3DAWC. It was observed that as the impact energy increases, both the maximum impact load and deflection also increases. The load-displacement curves and failure mode between experimental and FEM were compared and the reasonable agreements were found. It was concluded that the unit cell model of 3DAWC is effective and accurate. However, we should point out that the plastic effect was not involved in the FEM model so the prediction of the maximum impact displacement of composites is underestimated. To solve this problem, we must consider the real microstructure of the composite and the progressive failure of the unit cell model under impact.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors acknowledge the financial supports from the National Science Foundation of China (Grant Numbers 10802022, 10872049 and 11072058) and the Key-grant Project of Chinese Ministry of Education (No. 309014). The supports from Foundation for the Author of National Excellent Doctoral Dissertation of PR China (FANEDD, No. 201056), Shanghai Rising-Star Program (11QH1400100) and the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China are also gratefully acknowledged.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
